ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Brian David Drollette  Brian Drollette
Instructor: Brian David Drollette  Brian.
Instructor: Brian David Drollette  Brian
Instructor: Brian David Drollette  Brian Drollette
Instructor: Brian David Drollette  Drollette, Brian
Instructor: Brian David Drollette  Brian Drollette was the only Teaching Fellow for this course.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Brian David Drollette  Strengths: explained things clearly
Instructor: Brian David Drollette  Able to answer questions clearly and point out possible misconceptions in the discussions

Instructor: Brian David Drollette  I thought Brian was incredibly knowledgeable and able to answer just about any question I posed to him. He was very patient with all the students during his office hours.I found him to be a very helpful resource throughout the class.

Instructor: Brian David Drollette  Knew material very well, in some cases more than the professor. Very patient with students, and able to work with students at all levels of previous understanding. Just generally a nice guy

Instructor: Brian David Drollette  Brian was always extremely helpful during the TA office hours for problem sets. He had a strong knowledge of the course material and was very communicative in relaying that knowledge to students. No improvement needed.
Instructor: Brian David Drollette  He was always there, knowledgeable and super friendly. No improvement needed!

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Would have loved to go on a couple field trips to visit some clean-up sites.

With regards to Question 4, I found the pace of the course to be a little quick at times. I don't think this was a function of the teaching but rather how much material was covered. I sometimes had to review my notes and the lecture slides to fully grasp the concepts. That said, I don't think any material should be cut from the lectures. Ultimately I think that the lecture notes that the professor made available online were very helpful for mitigating this effect.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Shimi's teaching style, he took very difficult concepts and explained them in very, very understandable ways. He was approachable and kind. I also really appreciated that he printed out the slides and then we could take notes on them as he was talking. He was very timely with assignments and was organized.
Very well organized topics
Useful information, Chemical fundamentals.

The problem sets were super helpful as they forced us to review the material we learned in class and keep the lectures fresh in our minds.I also thought that the clicker questions were a great way to have a low stakes way of checking in on our attention span throughout the class. Response questions are also good and I like that they weren't every class.

Shimi has pre-filtered material to only focus on what's relevant, so you don't need to actually learn all of organic chemistry in order to understand how organic pollutants work and what's relevant for managing organic pollutants in an urban environment. Shimi has curated the curriculum into bite-size chunks and created problem sets to feed you the material on a silver platter.

The best aspect of the course by far was Professor Shimi Anisfeld's teaching. Shimi clearly cares a lot about the students and the course material. He was extremely knowledgable about the material and presented it in a very clear and concise manner. Furthermore, Shimi was patient with answering student's questions and comments during class. I also appreciated the number of office hours that were offered each week, which gave students an opportunity to grasp concepts that may have been covered too quickly during class. Finally, the brief organic chemistry review at the beginning of the course was very helpful for me since I had little previous experience with organic chemistry.
The learning curve in this course is incredible!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Could use some case studies from other countries
Updates and follow up on the study case that is presenting in class.

I think the end of the course is still kind of a whirlwind and it's hard to keep track of all of the different characteristics. Part of me thinks that a problem set put in those last few weeks that involve some kind of review of all the different groups of compounds would be really useful.

It's hard to prioritize the information in the course. A couple of examples: - for problem sets, class response qs, and exam problems, the key formula or fact is buried on a slide in the lecture - it wasn't apparent in the lecture at how important this one equation would be later on. He does try and highlight some of these as he goes through, but some are not emphasized as much in lecture as they are on the problem sets - there was a heavy emphasis on delta h and g and the various theoretical underpinnings of how and why certain organic pollutants respond to various external stimuli, but in the end I felt that this focus confused me more than helped me. I did come into the class with 0 organic chemistry experience, so perhaps different for those who wanted the full theoretical understanding - I just personally do better to learn the applied case first and then learn the why second. This course does the opposite. Also the focus on the structural isomers at the beginning was a distraction I think. Additionally, - would have preferred the class response questions to be due at the start of the next class instead of halfway, I often didn't have time for this course when the response question was due, but would have preferred to have spent the hour before class refreshing my mind on the previous class' material. - I was caught off guard by the no-open book midterm and expectations of memorizing the various names of chemicals. Probably my fault for not noticing, but I don't see why this course shouldn't have open-note tests given that any work in this field will be done by referencing various fact sheets, and is not a subject that you would be pulling info from the back of your mind willy-nilly. It's also a ton of work/huge learning curve to learn the names and terminology, moreso than I think is appreciated by Shimi. Once you learn it, it's very obvious, but the little basic things were such a struggle for me to get up to speed on terminology that it blocked me from fully grasping the material.
In my opinion there are no major aspects of the course that need improvement.
It was a great course. I think I learned a lot from unter student discussions, too especially before exams. Maybe that could be (further) facilitated. Otherwise no improvements come to mind.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Really appreciated the 3D modeling workshop. Could even have had more workshops like this, if applicable.
Very effective and well organized. No improvements come to mind.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Working in chemical engineering, need to know the types of contaminants I will aim to remove from the environment.
I think this is a very good course to take for anyone wishing to become a practitioner of environmental science.

This was a really useful course because it dives into chemistry in a way that's accessible and useful for people in our program. It's still hard, but I do think that I've gained another scientific layer of understanding through this course.

Took this class because I am interested in urban parks and open space and wanted a class related to water or chemistry in the urban environment - there were basically no water classes offered in the previous 3 semesters, so took this one as a backup. Didn't know the difference between organic pollutants, metals, and dissolved solids prior to taking this course, so really starting at ground zero. Was a terrific course in bringing me up to speed on the terminology of issues with brownfields and i look forward to utilizing this knowledge to identify opportunities in urban reclamation projects and be able to help me identify experts who know what they are talking about instead of flying blind.
I am interested in water resources engineering and this course covers material that fills a gap in my knowledge of environmental chemistry.
One of the few applied chemistry courses. Highly valuable!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Recommended from advisor
To gain fundamentals for my ongoing research.
I wanted to review some chemistry while learning about implications of chemical contamination events.

I took the class because I wanted a stronger organic chemistry background in an applied sense. I thought this was particularly useful in accomplishing that task. However I do wish there were case studies that perhaps were more immediate?Like those that hadn't taken place. I also wish we had sort of had an opportunity to summarize all of the different case studies in a meaningful way.
see above
I took this course because of the extremely positive reviews of the professor and because the content of the course fills an important knowledge gap for me.
I take all courses with Shimon Anisfeld: he teaches in my field and I learn more in his courses than in most others.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I actually thought it was going to be more chemistry-based. But it was still great! Just much more "big-picture" than I thought it was going to be.
Yes.
Yes
Yes! I learned a ton in this class and hope that it will stick with me into the future.

yes - it was very chemistry focused but that was known going in. I like taking classes where everybody knows more than I do and are over my head moreso than classes that are dumbed down. This class satisfied my expectations of a graduate level course.

Yes, the knowledge/skills that I gained from this course exceeded my expectations. Having little past experience with organic chemistry, I was expecting to be overwhelmed with the chemistry of the course, but Shimi does an excellent job of covering this foundational knowledge early on. Furthermore, I learned much more in depth knowledge about organic contaminants and their behavior in water than I had anticipated.
It surpassed my expectations by far (but pleasantly so).

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We had to do the model-building session in groups. It was fun and efficient since some people (like myself) have already forgotten about their basic chemistry. Having other people work with you makes the exercise faster.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's definitely worth taking.

I would say just be prepared to work hard and use the frequent office hours as much as possible. They're very useful in helping to review information and working on the weekly problem sets. It can quickly become overwhelming, so you need to stay on top of each weeks exercises. The midterm and final are pretty hefty so be prepared to put in some time studying for those. I took this course without an organic chemistry background and found that some of the topics just weren't as intuitive to me as a could've been. But I didn't see it as an extreme disadvantage, as most people had forgotten the organic chemistry they taken years ago anyway.

Learn the terminology of the various compounds early on - try to take the first quiz without notes, it will help you later on. Go to office hours - he sets aside office hours twice a week and the TA has one a week, and these are incredibly useful. They are both so patient and helpful, that it's a crying shame not to take advantage of them. Try and find additional problem sets to run through examples so you have more opportunities to practice the material. Don't stress, just learn what you can!
Be prepared to work a lot, but it's fun and so worth it!
